content: The Act may be cited as the "Citizens' Protection From Violent Crime Act of 1995". The Congress finds that government's duty is to protect citizens from armed violent criminals, but gun control laws do not achieve this as criminals still acquire firearms. These laws disarm law-abiding citizens and criminalize the possession of certain guns even for lawful purposes. The Second Amendment guarantees the right to possess firearms for self-defense, as people in the US often rely on firearms for protection when police cannot always be there to help. Mandatory prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm or destructive device during a state crime that is a serious violent felony or serious drug offense. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include mandatory prison terms for possessing or brandishing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking crime in federal court. Possessing a firearm results in a 5-year sentence, while brandishing a firearm results in a 10-year sentence. The amended Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, mandates prison terms for using a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possessing a firearm leads to a 5-year sentence, while discharging a firearm with intent to injure results in a 20-year sentence. Additional sentences apply for specific types of firearms, such as short-barreled rifles or shotguns, machine guns, destructive devices, or firearms equipped with silencers or mufflers. SEC. 4 amends Section 924(a)(2) of title 18, imposing mandatory prison sentences for individuals with prior serious violent felony convictions. A minimum of 5 years for one prior conviction and 10 years for two prior convictions. SEC. 5 includes serious juvenile drug offenses as predicates for the Armed Career Criminal Act. SEC. 5 amends Section 924(e)(2)(A) of title 18 to include serious juvenile drug offenses as predicates for the Armed Career Criminal Act. SEC. 6 amends Section 3156(a)(4) of title 18, United States Code to include pretrial detention for possession of firearms or explosives by convicted violent felons. SEC. 7 introduces the Armed Violent Criminal Apprehension Directive. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Each US attorney must designate a prosecutor and create a task force to remove armed violent criminals from the streets. The task force will focus on severe punishment as a deterrent and consider Federal and State laws for apprehension and prosecution. The Attorney General shall require each United States attorney to report monthly on the number of defendants charged with violating specific sections of the United States Code in their district. The Attorney General appoints an attorney and submits information to Congress twice a year, including waivers granted. A US attorney can request a waiver from the Attorney General for certain requirements, which can be granted based on established guidelines. The number of assistant United States attorneys in the office of the United States attorney making the request and the level of violent crime in the district are factors considered. An "armed violent criminal" is defined as someone accused of violating specific sections of the United States Code. This section will expire after a 5-year period following the enactment of the Act. SEC. 8. RIGHT TO USE FIREARMS IN DEFENSE OF SELF OR OTHER PERSONS WITHIN A HOME; ENFORCEMENT. The right to use firearms within a home for self-defense against imminent threats of serious bodily harm is reaffirmed. The term "firearm" includes shotguns, rifles, and handguns. Individuals whose rights are violated can seek damages through legal action in federal court. Individuals can seek damages in federal court for violations of their right to use firearms for self-defense. The court may award attorney's fees to the prevailing plaintiff and has a 5-year statute of limitations for bringing such actions.
